title: How to Pick the Right Hemline for a Skirt

steps.headline: Try a mini skirt if you have a short stature.
steps.description: Mini skirts show more skin, creating the illusion of a longer leg. If you have a height of 5'4" (about 163 centimeters) or less, a skirt that falls out somewhere between your mid-thigh and knee will provide your legs with the greatest amount of length.

steps.headline: Avoid midi and maxi skirts if you have short legs.
steps.description: Skirts that drag down to your calf or ankle can overwhelm your lower half with too much fabric, making you look short and frumpy as a result. If you do opt for a longer skirt, go for a fitted style that hugs your legs instead of a full, flowing style.

steps.headline: Experiment with midi skirts if your height ranges between average and tall.
steps.description: Midi skirts fall out at the mid-calf and may divide the length of your legs in a way that also shortens the appearance. If you do not need to worry about this shortening effect, however, a midi skirt may make a nice option.

steps.headline: Play with long skirts if you are tall.
steps.description: Long gypsy skirts can look especially elegant on taller women, since the extra fabric compliments their figure rather than overwhelming it. Stick with a hemline that stops just above your ankles. Showing the thinnest part of your ankles keeps your legs looking lean and slender.

steps.headline: Wear a knee-length skirt when in doubt.
steps.description: Knee-length skirts are virtually universally flattering. They prevent short women from looking any shorter and show off an appropriate, flattering amount of skin on average and tall women.

steps.headline: Stick with knee-length skirts if you have wider hips and thighs.
steps.description: Mini skirts tend to have a hemline that falls out over the widest part of your thighs, accentuating this problem area. Look for hemlines that stop a couple of inches above or below your knee to balance out your legs.

steps.headline: Try a mini skirt if you have full legs.
steps.description: If your legs are full from top to bottom, a mini skirt may help elongate your leg by showing off more skin. An elongated leg also means a slenderized leg.

steps.headline: Avoid mini skirts if you have a full mid-section.
steps.description: Women who carry excess weight around their stomachs need longer hemlines to keep their body looking proportioned. Short hemlines will only draw further attention to a large midsection.

steps.headline: Show off your legs if you have an athletic build.
steps.description: Try a mini skirt if you feel proud of your toned legs, or look for a fit-and-flare skirt with a hemline just below the knee if you want to make your muscular calves look slimmer.

steps.headline: Wear a midi skirt if you have slender calves.
steps.description: Not many women can pull of the midi skirt because it lands at the thickest part of the calves, which generally makes your legs look stout. If you have slender calves, however, you can usually wear a midi without worry.

steps.headline: Resist the temptation to hide beneath a long skirt if you are a plus sized woman.
steps.description: Baggy clothes do flatter plus sized women and tend to make them look dowdy. Instead of a long, baggy skirt, opt for a knee-length skirt with a little stretch and flare.

steps.headline: Stay away from long skirts if you are especially thin-boned.
steps.description: If your entire frame is thin, the excess fabric of a maxi skirt may threaten to swallow you up. If you do opt for a maxi skirt regardless, look for a sleek style that hugs your hips and thighs to reduce the amount of excess fabric.

steps.headline: Stand in front of a full-length mirror.
steps.description: Wear the shoes you plan on wearing with your skirt. If you have not decided on one pair of shoes, wear shoes with a heel height you tend to favor most.

steps.headline: Hold a piece of long fabric in front of your legs.
steps.description: The fabric should be able to cover your entire leg from top to bottom.

steps.headline: Gradually inch the fabric higher, exposing more of your leg.
steps.description: The first perspective hemline should be below your ankles, skimming the floor. This mimics the hemline of a maxi skirt.

steps.headline: Inch the fabric up to your mid-calf.
steps.description: This mimics the length of a midi skirt.

steps.headline: Inch the fabric up to your knee area.
steps.description: Test the entire knee area, including hemlines that stop on the knee and those that stop an inch below or above the knee.

steps.headline: Inch the fabric up to your mid-thigh.
steps.description: This length mimics the hemline of a mini skirt.
